H0.text: Ozone is the greenhouse gas whose amount in the air will increase the most if large forests are cut down to be used for building materials without planting new trees in their place.

H1.text: Methane is the greenhouse gas whose amount in the air will increase the most if large forests are cut down to be used for building materials without planting new trees in their place.

H2.text: Water vapor is the greenhouse gas whose amount in the air will increase the most if large forests are cut down to be used for building materials without planting new trees in their place.

H3.text: Carbon dioxide is the greenhouse gas whose amount in the air will increase the most if large forests are cut down to be used for building materials without planting new trees in their place.

A4.text: Contrary to the long-standing view that they are carbon neutral, mature forests can continue to accumulate carbon and remain valuable carbon sinks, helping to maintain the carbon balance of Earth's atmosphere.

A5.text: About half of excess CO2 emissions to the atmosphere are absorbed by land and ocean carbon sinks.
